data.itemTitle: Open Source, Agents, and the Next AI Wave w/ Angie Jones
data.showNotes:
Recorded live at All Things Open, Robbie Wagner and guest co-host Jason Lengstorf talk with Angie Jones about AI, coding models, and the evolving landscape of open source. They unpack the importance of community-driven tooling, skill gaps in using AI, the future of agentic systems, and why open communities matter in shaping technology.
In this episode:
(00:00) - Intro
(01:18) - Wine rating & review
(03:30) - Hot Take: Claude vs ChatGPT
(04:20) - Hot Take: Is HTML a programming language?
(04:56) - Hot Take: Is CSS a programming language?
(05:31) - Hot Take: Is AI to blame when people do dumb shit with it?
(09:50) - How open source shaped Angie‚Äôs career
(14:54) - The problem with AI training on open source data
(23:02) - What is MCP and why does it matter?
(25:10) - Using MCP when you don‚Äôt follow every part of the spec
(26:25) - Are we building new walled gardens inside MCP?
(31:16) - Building DevRel in a rapidly-changing AI landscape
(36:06) - Conference season stress & preparing new talks
(39:41) - Where to find Angie online

data.itemTitle: 689: Tyler Sticka on Colorpeek 2 and Awesome CSS
data.showNotes:
Show Description
In this episode we sit down with Tyler Sticka to discuss upgrading his project, Colorpeek. We explore the practical applications of web components and CSS, and how they are shaping the future of web development. Tyler shares his experiences with prototyping and the challenges of maintaining simplicity in design.

data.itemTitle: Episode 485: I'm terrible at hiring decisions and my coworker spams us with AI-generated memes
data.showNotes:
In this episode, Dave and Jamison answer these questions:
What signals do you look for when interviewing candidates? I‚Äôve helped interview many people at this point and almost all of the engineers that I marked as ‚Äúhire‚Äù that we brought on board ended up being low performers and were eventually managed out. I wasn‚Äôt the only one who approved them either, so not all the blame falls on me, but I‚Äôm really doubting my ability to assess talent.
Is hiring inherently just this difficult?
Is there anything I can do to improve my judgement or screening approach?
Hi Dave and Jamison,
A coworker on my team won‚Äôt stop creating AI generated memes.
We‚Äôre a remote team and every meeting he shares memes in the chat whilst we‚Äôre trying to have productive conversations. He does this in any type of meeting, including all-hands meetings with C-level execs. On smaller calls he often hijacks it to share his screen and show us a meme he just created about something that was just said.
It started off funny at first. But it‚Äôs now a constant distraction.
I find it frustrating because I don‚Äôt see how he can be paying attention and contributing to discussions when he‚Äôs busy making memes. And, I also don‚Äôt appreciate seeing AI versions of my own face being shared into public Slack channels.
How can I address this without sounding like I am anti-fun?
Love the show, been listening for many years, keep up the good work!

data.itemTitle: 120: Is the AI Bubble About to Burst?
data.showNotes:
It‚Äôs been almost 3 weeks since the React Compiler hit v1.0 and Jack gives an update on the ease of adding it to a React-based project and immediate performance improvement he‚Äôs seen from it.¬†
Popular AI-powered IDE Cursor just released v2.0, and it‚Äôs going hard on the agent mode, offering things like: a multi-agent interface where agents can run in parallel working on the same task with different models, and a new frontier model that‚Äôs 4x faster.
Then the hosts then get existential about whether the AI hype bubble is about to burst, if it‚Äôs really capable of stealing anyone‚Äôs jobs, and how much you should trust an LLM when making decisions about things like the tech stack for a new project.¬†
Timestamps:

1:43 - React Compiler 1.0
8:13 - Cursor 2.0
22:28 - AI discussion on bubbles and more
43:13 - What‚Äôs making us happy

News:

data.itemTitle: Speeding up the web with the speculation rules API | Barry Pollard
data.showNotes:
Barry Pollard from the Chrome devrel team joins PodRocket to discuss the speculation rules API, a new browser feature designed to improve web performance through prefetch and pre-render techniques. Barry breaks down the history of speculative loading, contrasts SPA vs MPA behavior, and explains the nuances of hover prefetching, conservative prefetch, and the powerful new pre-render until script mode. Learn how Shopify and WordPress are adopting the API, what telemetry from Chrome Status reveals, and what developers need to know about potential pitfalls, caching behavior, and how the API is becoming a standard for static sites and e-commerce performance.
Links
Website: https://www.tunetheweb.com
X: https://x.com/tunetheweb
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/tunetheweb
Github: https://github.com/tunetheweb

Scott and Wes dive into Remix 3, exploring how it embraces native web standards like Events, Signals, and Streams to become a truly full-stack framework. They unpack what ‚ÄúLLM-ready,‚Äù thin APIs, and a standards-based approach mean for the future of web development.
